effective_dosage: 1 weekly supervised exercise session plus home-based exercise prescription (specific frequency/duration not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate whether soft robotic exosuits (REAL) enhance rehabilitative outcomes of high-intensity gait training compared to training without exosuits (CONTROL) in post-stroke individuals.
results_summary: REAL gait training significantly improved 6MWT distance (68±27 m vs. 30±16 m) and 10mWT speed (0.08±0.03 m/s vs. 0.01±0.06 m/s) compared to CONTROL, with 75% of participants surpassing MCIDs after REAL training. Biomechanical improvements, such as paretic propulsion, were also more pronounced with REAL.
population_specificity: Four individuals post-stroke.
effective_dosage: Twelve visits (six REAL, six CONTROL) of speed-based high-intensity gait training.
study_duration: Six consecutive visits per intervention arm, separated by 6+ weeks of washout.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the relationship between the effects of intradialytic exercise (including walking) and aging in older patients.
results_summary: All age groups improved in isometric knee extension strength and Short Physical Performance Battery scores, but the 80-89 age group did not show significant improvement in 10-m walking speed or nutritional status. Older groups generally had smaller improvements compared to the younger control group.
population_specificity: Older patients (aged 40-89 years) undergoing dialysis.
effective_dosage: Intradialytic exercise program (stretching and resistance training) three times per week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the relationship between cognitive and motor performance in individuals with mild traumatic brain injury (mTBI) and compare these performances to healthy controls.
results_summary: Individuals with mTBI performed worse on cognitive and several physical performance assessments compared to healthy controls. Complex motor tasks combined with cognitive demands were more strongly related to cognitive assessments than simple walking tasks.
population_specificity: Adults with mild traumatic brain injury (mTBI) and healthy controls.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate changes in gait function for chronic spinal cord injury (SCI) patients after standard rehabilitation and robot-assisted gait training (RAGT), and assess the safety and dosage of RAGT.
results_summary: Gait speed improved after both standard rehabilitation and RAGT, with cadence influenced by standard rehabilitation and step length by RAGT. Hip flexor function improvement during RAGT was linked to increased step length.
population_specificity: Twelve patients with chronic spinal cord injury.
study_duration: Standard rehabilitation for 66.1 ± 36.9 days, followed by RAGT for 17.6 ± 3.3 days.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether physical activity and exercise improve fitness, mobility, and functional capacity in adults with lower limb amputation, and to identify the type and minimum effective dose of such activity.
results_summary: Mixed exercise programs combining aerobic exercise with strengthening or balance exercises showed the highest evidence for improving balance, walking speed, walking endurance, and transfer ability. However, there was low confidence in improvements for cardiorespiratory health, muscle strength, flexibility, and functional capacity due to insufficient studies.
population_specificity: Adults with lower limb amputation living in the community.
effective_dosage: 1-3 sessions of 20-60 minutes of exercise per week.

study_goal: To determine the effects of anodal tDCS combined with overground gait training on gait performance, dynamic balance, sit-to-stand performance, and quality of life in individuals with incomplete spinal cord injuries (iSCI).
results_summary: The anodal tDCS group showed greater improvements in walking speed (10MWT) and stride length compared to the sham group, with effects sustained for 2 months. No significant differences were found for dynamic balance, functional tasks, or quality of life.
population_specificity: Individuals with incomplete spinal cord injuries (n=34).
effective_dosage: Anodal tDCS at 2 mA for 20 min, combined with 40 min of overground gait training, for 5 consecutive daily sessions.
study_duration: 5 days of intervention, with follow-ups at 1 and 2 months.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether adding chest wall mobilizations to a standardized walking exercise program improves respiratory outcomes in patients with severe COPD.
results_summary: The study found that additional chest wall mobilizations significantly improved respiratory muscle strength, thoracic excursion, and thoracic range of movement (except flexion) compared to walking exercise alone. These improvements were strongly associated with enhanced lower thoracic excursion and respiratory muscle function.
population_specificity: Thirty male adults (mean age 74.97 ± 6.29) with severe COPD.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether perturbation-based balance training (PBT) using the mobile Tethered Pelvic Assist Device (mTPAD) improves cognitive and functional outcomes in older adults during overground walking.
results_summary: The experimental group (EG) using mTPAD PBT showed significant improvements in cognitive (SDMT-C, TMT-B) and functional (BBS, 4-Stage Balance) measurements compared to the control group (CG), along with increased mobility confidence (FES-I).
population_specificity: Forty healthy older adults (aged not specified).
effective_dosage: Not specified (two-day study with one day of training).
study_duration: Two days (one day of baseline measurements, one day of intervention).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of early versus late rehabilitation (including walking) on low back pain and quality of life after unilateral microdiscectomy.
results_summary: Walking initiated in the 2nd week post-surgery showed significant pain reduction (VAS scores) and improved disability (ODI scores) compared to no exercise or later interventions. The no-exercise group consistently had worse outcomes at long-term follow-ups.
population_specificity: 204 patients who underwent surgery for lumbar disc herniation.
study_duration: Follow-up assessments at 1 week, 1, 3, 6, and 12 months post-surgery.

study_goal: To determine the effect of aerobic exercise (walking) on cardiorespiratory fitness, body size, and quality of life among men on active surveillance for low-risk prostate cancer.
results_summary: The home-based walking program improved cardiorespiratory fitness (VO2 peak) and quality of life in the intervention group compared to controls. The study demonstrated that moderate to vigorous aerobic exercise is beneficial for men on active surveillance.
population_specificity: Men with low-risk prostate cancer on active surveillance.
effective_dosage: Home-based walking program with a nonlinear exercise prescription tailored to baseline fitness level, using a heart rate monitor.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate and compare different methods for assessing functional capacity in patients with peripheral artery disease (PAD) and claudication symptoms.
results_summary: The study found that treadmill and six-minute walk tests are well-supported for assessing functional capacity in PAD patients due to their clinical relevance and sensitivity to interventions. Other tests, while practical, require further validation regarding reliability and long-term intervention effects.
population_specificity: Patients with peripheral artery disease (PAD) and claudication symptoms.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of Baduanjin exercise versus walking in reducing pain and improving lumbar muscle function in patients with chronic nonspecific low back pain.
results_summary: Walking showed some improvement in lumbar muscle activity (FLEXAEMG and EXTAEMG) but was less effective than Baduanjin in reducing pain (numeric pain rating scale) and disability (Oswestry Disability Index). The Baduanjin group demonstrated superior outcomes in all measured parameters.
population_specificity: 60 patients diagnosed with chronic nonspecific low back pain from Hubei Provincial Hospital of Traditional Chinese Medicine.

study_goal: To compare the effectiveness of cognitively enhanced tai ji quan versus standard tai ji quan or stretching exercise in improving global cognition and reducing dual-task walking costs in older adults with MCI or self-reported memory concerns.
results_summary: Cognitively enhanced tai ji quan outperformed standard tai ji quan and stretching, showing greater improvements in global cognition (MoCA score) and dual-task walking costs, with effects persisting at 48-week follow-up.
population_specificity: Older adults with self-reported memory decline or concern and a Clinical Dementia Rating (CDR) global score of 0.5 or lower.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the feasibility of implementing multimodal agility-based exercise training (MAT) for persons with multiple sclerosis (pwMS) in an inpatient rehabilitation setting and compare it to traditional strength and endurance training (SET).
results_summary: Both MAT and SET groups showed similar short-term fatigue reduction and improved motor fatigability, but cognitive fatigability worsened. MAT demonstrated clinically meaningful improvement in walking endurance (43.9 m), exceeding minimal important change values.
population_specificity: Persons with multiple sclerosis (pwMS) with low to moderate disability and self-reported fatigue.
effective_dosage: MAT: 5x/week gym sessions, 3x/week pool sessions; SET: 5x/week cycle ergometer, 3x/week strength training.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effects of a six-week Nordic walking training regimen on serum iron metabolism parameters and leukocyte gene expression in multiple myeloma patients.
results_summary: The study found a declining trend in serum ferritin concentrations and positive influences on leukocyte gene expression related to iron metabolism after Nordic walking training, suggesting potential benefits for disease progression, though longer training periods may be needed for significant effects.
population_specificity: Thirty multiple myeloma patients (mean age ~63 years), divided into an exercise group (n=15) and a control group (n=15).
study_duration: Six weeks of training, with follow-up at nine weeks.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of elastic band training versus group-based dance on physical-functional performance, including walking speed, in older women with sarcopenia.
results_summary: Elastic band training significantly improved fat-free mass, upper and lower limb muscle strength, and decreased time in timed up-and-go (TUG) and walking speed compared to group-based dance.
population_specificity: Older women with sarcopenia.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of an E-coach chronic disease management model in improving rehabilitation behavior management, including walking performance, in patients with arteriosclerosis obliterans (ASO).
results_summary: The E-coach group showed significantly better outcomes in blood pressure and glucose control, drug compliance, and walking performance (6MWT and PFWD scores) compared to the control group at 1 and 6 months post-intervention.
population_specificity: Patients with arteriosclerosis obliterans (ASO).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of a combined dietary intervention (COMB-FP meal) and exercise program, including walking, in improving frailty-related outcomes such as walking speed and cognitive function in pre-frail or frail older adults.
results_summary: The study found that the test group (exercise plus COMB-FP meal) showed significant improvements in walking speed and cognitive function compared to the exercise-only control group. Similar positive trends were observed in other frailty-related outcomes, including microbiome composition, well-being, and oxidative stress.
population_specificity: 110 healthy male and female volunteers with pre-frailty or frailty.
effective_dosage: Two daily meals replaced with COMB-FP meals (specific nutrient composition not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of lower limb resistance training on body structure and function, activity (including gait/walking speed), and participation outcomes in individuals with chronic stroke.
results_summary: Lower limb resistance training improved muscle strength (knee extensors, flexors, leg press) but showed no significant improvements in mobility, gait (walking speed), or quality of life in chronic stroke patients.
population_specificity: Individuals with chronic stroke.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether combining self-efficacy intervention with the Otago Exercise Program (OEP) could improve recovery, reduce fall risk, and enhance quality of life in older discharged patients.
results_summary: The study found that the combined intervention significantly improved self-efficacy, balance, walking speed, daily functioning, and quality of life while reducing fall risk compared to OEP alone. These improvements were consistent across multiple assessment points (days 15, 30, 45, and 60).
population_specificity: Elderly patients (aged 65+) recently discharged from healthcare facilities.
effective_dosage: 3 times per week, 30-45 minutes per session.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a telenursing intervention program could reduce exacerbations in patients with chronic respiratory failure receiving noninvasive positive pressure ventilation (NPPV) at home.
results_summary: The telenursing intervention significantly reduced the number of hospitalizations, hospital days, and unscheduled outpatient visits for acute exacerbations, while also improving scores on the St. George's Respiratory Questionnaire and Self-Care Agency Questionnaire. However, there was an increase in unscheduled outpatient visits attributed to acute exacerbations in the intervention group.
population_specificity: Patients with chronic respiratory failure receiving NPPV at home who could handle a tablet device.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the dose-response effects of resistance training on muscle strength and physical fitness in frail older adults.
results_summary: Resistance training showed dose-dependent improvements in muscle strength and physical fitness, with high-intensity training being more effective for muscle strength and high-volume training improving 30sSTST and 6MWT performances. Low-moderate intensity and volume training also had safety and efficacy advantages.
population_specificity: Frail older adults
effective_dosage: Various intensities (low, moderate, high) and volumes (moderate, high) of resistance training

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess persistent balance limitations, fall risk, and physical activity levels in individuals after mild stroke compared to healthy controls.
results_summary: Participants after mild stroke had higher fall rates, worse balance (lower mini-BEST scores), slower mobility (TUG and 10-MWT), and reduced activity confidence (6-ABC) compared to healthy controls, with lower activity intensity but similar duration.
population_specificity: Individuals in the chronic phase (>6 months post-stroke) with mild motor/sensory leg impairment and near-complete motor function recovery.
study_duration: 7 days for activity measurement, 12 months for fall rate recording.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the functional association between posture, spinal balance, ambulatory biomechanics, paraspinal muscle fatigue, and symptoms in patients with symptomatic lumbar spinal stenosis (sLSS) before and after surgical intervention.
results_summary: The study protocol describes a multimodal approach to assess biomechanical and clinical outcomes in sLSS patients, but no specific results regarding Walking's effects are provided in the abstract.
population_specificity: Patients with symptomatic lumbar spinal stenosis (sLSS).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the minimal clinically important differences (MCIDs) for walking capacity and physical activity in patients with lumbar spinal stenosis (LSS) receiving nonsurgical treatment.
results_summary: The study found MCIDs of 151 meters for the self-paced walking test (SPWT) and 1,149 steps for daily activity using an anchor-based approach, and 280 meters for SPWT and 1,274 steps using a distribution-based approach. The anchor-based approach showed limited external responsiveness when using the Zurich Claudication Questionnaire (ZCQ) as an anchor.
population_specificity: Sixty-nine patients with neurogenic claudication caused by LSS receiving outpatient physical therapy.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether long-term and short-term Tai Chi training could mitigate age-related declines in physical function, including walking, in healthy older adults.
results_summary: Long-term Tai Chi training was associated with better physical function in older adults, comparable to younger adults, while short-term training showed small, non-significant effects.
population_specificity: Healthy older adults (TC-naïve and TC-experts) and younger adults.
study_duration: 6 months for the short-term trial; long-term TC experts had 24.5 ± 12 years of experience.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the one-year impact of three exercise strategies (unsupervised Nordic pole walk advice, home-based structured exercise, and hospital-based supervised exercise) on health-related quality of life and patient-reported physical function in patients with intermittent claudication.
results_summary: The study found clinically important improvements in the hospital-based supervised exercise group using the VascuQoL, but no significant between-group differences were observed using the SF-36. Effect sizes for changes over time were generally small, but a higher proportion of patients in the supervised exercise group reached the minimally important difference threshold for improvement.
population_specificity: Patients with intermittent claudication (mean age 72.1 years, 41% women).
effective_dosage: Not specified (exercise strategies included unsupervised Nordic pole walk advice, home-based structured exercise, and hospital-based supervised exercise).
study_duration: Six months of structured exercise (home-based or hospital-based) with one-year follow-up.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop and validate a method (ToulGaitViz) for quantifying and visualizing lower limb kinematics during the swing phase of gait in post-stroke hemiparetic subjects to better understand shortening defaults and compensatory movements.
results_summary: The study found that post-stroke hemiparetic subjects relied more on compensatory movements (e.g., limb abduction, hip hiking) for limb clearance during gait compared to healthy controls. ToulGaitViz effectively quantified these differences and provided a tool for visualizing kinematic changes before and after therapeutic interventions.
population_specificity: 151 post-stroke hemiparetic participants and 48 healthy control participants.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of end-effector lower limb rehabilitation robot training combined with conventional physiotherapy versus conventional physiotherapy alone on walking ability in subacute stroke patients.
results_summary: Both groups showed significant improvement in all outcome measures, but the robot-assisted training group demonstrated greater improvement in functional ambulatory category (FAC) compared to the control group.
population_specificity: Subacute stroke patients (n=49, divided into robot group n=26 and control group n=23).
effective_dosage: Robot group: 30-minute robot training + 1.5-hour conventional physiotherapy; control group: 2-hour conventional physiotherapy.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to systematically determine the effects of pulmonary rehabilitation, including walking-based interventions, on exercise capacity, symptoms, and quality of life in patients with sarcoidosis.
results_summary: Pulmonary rehabilitation, including walking interventions, significantly improved exercise capacity (measured by 6-minute walking test) and reduced dyspnoea perception in sarcoidosis patients, but did not affect fatigue, quality of life, or pulmonary function.
population_specificity: Symptomatic sarcoidosis patients (184 participants across five studies).
effective_dosage: Not specified (varied by study, including multi-component exercise, inspiratory muscle training, physical activity incentivisation, and telerehabilitation).
study_duration: Not specified (duration varied by included studies).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the long-term prognosis of patients with mPAP values between 21-24 mmHg versus those with mPAP <21 mmHg, focusing on clinical outcomes and mortality.
results_summary: Patients with mPAP 21-24 mmHg showed worse echocardiographic findings and deteriorated cardiac indices compared to those with mPAP <21 mmHg, though all-cause mortality differences were not statistically significant. The 6-minute walking distance was better in the mPAP <21 mmHg group.
population_specificity: Patients with moderate-to-high echocardiographic risk referred for pulmonary hypertension suspicion (mean age 53.1 ± 14.8 years, 74.5% female).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to establish the feasibility of a full-scale RCT investigating a combined education and exercise program versus a general advice program for people with ankle OA.
results_summary: The study will assess feasibility outcomes (e.g., recruitment, adherence, adverse events) and collect preliminary data on participant-reported and physical outcomes, but results are not yet available.
population_specificity: Individuals aged 35+ with symptomatic radiographic ankle OA.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify practical performance-based physical function instruments to monitor musculoskeletal health in people with haemophilia.
results_summary: The study identified 11 activities people with haemophilia struggle with, and through a DELPHI survey, consensus was reached on seven performance-based tests, including the 6-min walk test and timed up and down stairs, to monitor physical function.
population_specificity: People with haemophilia

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the association between continuously measured walking activity and the development of major depressive disorder (MDD).
results_summary: The study found that a formal MDD diagnosis was preceded by a decline in daily step counts approximately 2 weeks before diagnosis, followed by a gradual increase post-diagnosis and treatment. Step counts were significantly lower around the diagnosis date but rebounded over time.
population_specificity: Working-age Japanese individuals (20-74 years) with MDD diagnosis and step count data.
effective_dosage: Not specified (step counts measured, not prescribed).
study_duration: 120 days (60 days before and after MDD diagnosis).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the association between the pentagon-copying task (a cognitive measure) and physical/motor performance, including walking speed, in older adults, as well as its link to frailty.
results_summary: The study found that individuals who performed poorly on the pentagon-copying task had greater odds of strength deficits, frailty, and slower gait speed. The Qualitative Scoring Pentagon Test (QSPT) scores correlated significantly with handgrip strength and gait speed and inversely with frailty.
population_specificity: Older adults aged ≥65 years without severe neurocognitive disorders, psychiatric history, or severe upper limb/sensory deficits.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of nutritional supplement drinks (NSDs) and nutritional education (NE) on the nutritional status and physical performance of older nursing home residents at risk of malnutrition.
results_summary: The abstract does not provide specific results regarding Walking.
population_specificity: Older nursing home residents (aged 65+ years) at risk of malnutrition.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of traditional neurological rehabilitation versus rehabilitation combined with a rehabilitation robot for patients with post-COVID-19 fatigue syndrome.
results_summary: Both groups showed similar improvements during rehabilitation, but the intervention group (which included robot-assisted exercises) demonstrated better improvement in the Functional Independence Measure.
population_specificity: Eighty-six participants transferred from intensive care units due to post-viral fatigue after COVID-19.
effective_dosage: Control group: 120 min/day standard rehabilitation; Intervention group: 75 min/day standard rehabilitation + 45 min/day robot-assisted exercises.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the impact of lumbar spinal surgery on lipid metabolism in patients with lumbar spinal disorders (LSDs) and identify factors associated with changes in visceral fat accumulation, including preoperative walking ability.
results_summary: The study found that lumbar spinal surgery did not necessarily improve lipid metabolism in patients with LSDs; instead, female patients experienced worsened lipid metabolism post-surgery. Worse preoperative walking ability was associated with improved visceral fat accumulation after surgery.
population_specificity: Patients with lumbar spinal disorders (e.g., lumbar spinal canal stenosis, lumbar disk herniation) undergoing lumbar spinal surgery (n=138).
effective_dosage: Not applicable (surgical intervention, not a supplement).
study_duration: Evaluations were conducted before surgery and at 6 months and 1 year post-surgery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the potential benefits of spinal cord stimulation (SCS) for improving gait impairment in patients with advanced Parkinson's Disease.
results_summary: Among 106 patients, 90% showed improvement in Parkinson's Disease gait impairment and motor outcomes, with thoracic burst stimulation being the most common approach. The study noted limitations like small sample sizes and unblinded evaluations but suggested SCS may benefit a subset of patients.
population_specificity: Patients with advanced Parkinson's Disease and gait impairment (PDg).
effective_dosage: Not specified (most common stimulation location was thoracic, primarily T9-T10; burst sub-perception stimulation was the most common modality at 59%).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether synchronizing foot strikes with the diastolic phase of the cardiac cycle during walking improves stroke volume and cardiac output in patients with chronic congestive heart failure (CHF) and cardiac resynchronization therapy (CRT).
results_summary: The study found that diastolic stepping increased stroke volume and oxygen delivery while decreasing afterload in CHF patients with CRT, suggesting potential benefits for exercise participation and quality of life.
population_specificity: Ten participants (58±17 years; 40% female) with CHF and previously implanted CRT pacemakers.
effective_dosage: 5-minute bouts of walking at 1.5-3 mph, synchronized to auditory tones for foot strike timing.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the utility of the 6-minute walking test (6MWT) as a measure of exercise capacity and mortality risk stratification in patients with pulmonary hypertension (PH) and other cardiopulmonary diseases.
results_summary: The study found that the 6-minute walking distance (6MWD) is a validated endpoint in clinical trials for PH and serves as a key non-invasive measure for risk assessment, with specific cut-off values (440 m, 320 m, and 165 m) used to stratify mortality risk in pulmonary arterial hypertension (PAH).
population_specificity: Patients with pulmonary hypertension (PH) or other pulmonary or cardiac diseases.
effective_dosage: Not applicable (walking test, not a supplement).

study_goal: To determine the effects of extracorporeal shock wave therapy (ESWT) on lower limb function, walking, and quality of life in patients with lower limb poststroke spasticity.
results_summary: ESWT showed beneficial effects in reducing spasticity and improving lower limb motor function, but its effectiveness in walking performance remains uncertain.
population_specificity: Patients with lower limb poststroke spasticity (389 participants across 15 studies).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify the current prognostic value of walking speed (WS) for older adults across various health domains.
results_summary: Walking speed is a valuable prognostic tool for multiple health outcomes, including mental health, mortality, disability, and metabolic health. A WS slower than 1.0 m/s was commonly associated with increased risk or decline, while faster speeds (e.g., 1.32 m/s) indicated reduced risks like type 2 diabetes.
population_specificity: Older adults

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if functional electrical stimulation (FES) of the peroneal nerve could improve body functions, activities, and participation in children with unilateral spastic cerebral palsy compared to conventional treatment.
results_summary: FES did not significantly outperform conventional treatment in goal attainment but preserved increased ankle range of motion during walking. Therapy failed in four patients, while 12 continued FES post-trial.
population_specificity: 25 children (aged 4-18 years) with unilateral spastic cerebral palsy (Gross Motor Function Classification System levels I and II).
study_duration: Two 12-week treatment blocks separated by a 6-week washout period.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness and safety of total contact casts (TCCs) versus removable offloading interventions (removable walking casts and footwear) in healing diabetic foot ulcers (DFUs).
results_summary: TCCs showed higher healing rates and shorter healing times compared to removable walking casts and footwear but were associated with increased device-related complications. Subgroup analysis confirmed higher healing rates with TCCs, though complications were more frequent compared to footwear.
population_specificity: Patients with diabetic foot ulcers (591 participants, 269 in TCC group, 322 in control group).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the feasibility of a supervised blood flow restriction (BFR) exercise program in patients with claudication to improve exercise performance and quality of life.
results_summary: The BFR program showed high adherence (78.3%), no adverse events, and significant clinical improvements in walking (86% of patients) and time to claudication pain (35% increase). Quality of life metrics also improved in mobility, usual activities, pain, depression, and overall health.
population_specificity: Thirty patients with stable claudication.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of physical therapy (including walking) administered before versus after initial cancer treatment on exercise capacity and health-related quality of life in children with hematological cancers.
results_summary: Early physical therapy improved health-related quality of life but not exercise capacity (measured by 6MWD) in children with hematological cancers, while late physical therapy resulted in significant declines in both measures.
population_specificity: School children (7-13 years) with hematological cancers.
study_duration: Duration of initial cancer treatment (not explicitly stated)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate whether walking exercises could enhance bowel preparation before a colonoscopy procedure.
results_summary: Walking more than 6900 steps significantly improved bowel preparation scores, but the intervention group (assigned walking) did not show a statistically significant difference in mean BBPS scores compared to the control group. Older individuals and smokers derived fewer benefits from walking for bowel preparation.
population_specificity: 262 patients scheduled for colonoscopy procedures, randomized into intervention and control groups.
effective_dosage: Not specified (walking steps >6900 were associated with better outcomes).
study_duration: Not specified (intervention occurred before the colonoscopy procedure).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the pathophysiological mechanisms and clinical effects of physical exercise, including walking, on patients with chronic kidney disease (CKD) across various stages and treatments.
results_summary: Walking and other physical exercises improved functional capacity, cardiorespiratory fitness, and quality of life in CKD patients, though effects on kidney function were inconsistent. Exercise also reduced inflammation markers and fasting plasma glucose in pre-dialysis patients but did not significantly impact glucose metabolism or cholesterol levels in transplant recipients.
population_specificity: Patients with chronic kidney disease (CKD), including pre-dialysis, hemodialysis, peritoneal dialysis, and kidney transplant recipients.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the natural history of motor function, including walking ability, in patients with types 1-3 spinal muscular atrophy (SMA).
results_summary: The study found that untreated patients with type 3 SMA experience progressive loss of walking ability over time, with median times to loss of ambulation varying by subtype (13.4 years for type 3a and 44.2 years for type 3b). The results highlight the inevitability of motor function decline in SMA patients.
population_specificity: Patients with types 1-3 spinal muscular atrophy (SMA).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the diagnosis, treatment, and follow-up of X-linked hypophosphatemia (XLH) in a patient with a history of untreated symptoms, including skeletal abnormalities and walking disturbances.
results_summary: The study confirmed XLH diagnosis through imaging, laboratory, and genetic assessments. Phosphate tablets in adulthood improved clinical and physical outcomes, preventing further skeletal abnormalities and daily activity burdens.
population_specificity: A patient with untreated X-linked hypophosphatemia (XLH) and a family history of similar symptoms (short stature, bone pain, fractures).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of dalfampridine combined with physiotherapy on walking speed, muscle length, spasticity, functional strength, and functional mobility in patients with hereditary spastic paraplegia (HSP).
results_summary: The study found that dalfampridine significantly improved walking speed (T25FWT), muscle length, spasticity, and functional muscle strength compared to placebo, but no significant difference was observed in functional mobility. No adverse events or side effects were reported.
population_specificity: Patients with hereditary spastic paraplegia (HSP)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the hemodynamic improvements and safety of atrial septal defect (ASD) closure in patients with severe pulmonary arterial hypertension (PAH), including changes in 6-minute walking distance (6MWD).
results_summary: The study found significant improvements in 6MWD and other hemodynamic parameters, particularly in the treat-and-repair strategy subgroup, with low rates of major adverse cardiac events (MACEs).
population_specificity: Patients with severe PAH associated with atrial septal defect (ASD).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify gait parameters used in randomized controlled trials to assess intervention effects on mobility recovery in older adults after hip fracture.
results_summary: The study found that gait parameters, primarily gait speed in short walking tests, were the most frequently used measures in intervention studies, with only five studies utilizing wearable sensors for out-of-lab assessment. Evidence on mobility improvement remains largely limited to controlled settings, highlighting the need for more comprehensive, real-world gait assessments.
population_specificity: Older adults recovering from hip fracture (2,754 unique participants across 29 trials).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness and safety of various physical exercises, including walking, on outcomes like the six-minute walk test and quality of life in hemodialysis patients.
results_summary: Walking exercise (WE) was included among the interventions, but the abstract does not specify its individual efficacy compared to other exercises. The study found that aerobic exercise and combined resistance + aerobic exercise significantly improved outcomes, but walking's specific effects were not detailed.
population_specificity: Patients undergoing hemodialysis (HD).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether lower limb motor-evoked potentials (MEPs) one week post-stroke could predict recovery of independent walking, use of ankle-foot orthosis (AFO), or walking aids at 3 and 6 months post-stroke.
results_summary: Independent walking at 3 and 6 months post-stroke was better predicted by age, lower limb strength, and balance (92% accuracy) than by MEP status alone (73% accuracy). AFO use was better predicted by stroke severity (NIHSS) and MEP status (88% accuracy) than by MEP status alone (76% accuracy). No variables predicted the use of walking aids.
population_specificity: Non-ambulatory participants recruited 5 days post-stroke (median age 72 years, range 38-97 years).
study_duration: Assessments at 1 week, 3 months, and 6 months post-stroke.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the efficacy of brisk walking versus Yi Jin Jing exercise in improving cervical range of motion and relieving pain in adolescents with cervical spondylopathy.
results_summary: Brisk walking reduced Neck Disability Index (NDI) and pain visual analog scale (VAS) scores and improved cervical curvature, though less significantly than Yi Jin Jing. No adverse reactions were reported.
population_specificity: 60 adolescent patients with cervical spondylopathy (30 in the brisk walking group).
effective_dosage: Three times a week for at least 30 minutes.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to clarify the definition of "early mobilization" (walking within 3 days of admission) and evaluate its effectiveness and safety in patients with acute heart failure.
results_summary: Early mobilization may significantly reduce readmission rates (odds ratio 0.25, 95% CI 0.14 to 0.42) in acute HF patients, though the evidence is based on observational studies with no randomized controlled trials.
population_specificity: Hospitalized patients with acute heart failure.
effective_dosage: Walking within 3 days of admission (protocol-based interventions).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to describe how ambulatory adults with lower limb spasticity present for treatment in routine clinical practice, including functional limitations and treatment goals.
results_summary: The study found that most patients with lower limb spasticity had difficulty with indoor and outdoor walking, with 80.7% and 90.5% reporting at least mild difficulty, respectively. Despite relatively young age, only 20% were employed, and many had sensory, communication, or cognitive impairments.
population_specificity: Ambulatory adults (≥18 years) with unilateral lower limb spasticity, able to take ≥5 steps with or without assistance.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether longer-term adherence to regular walking, combined with a Mediterranean-style diet and delivered through motivational interviewing and cognitive-behavioral therapy (MI-CBT), could reduce age-associated cognitive decline and dementia risk factors in older adults.
results_summary: The study is ongoing, with baseline testing completed for 157 participants, but final results on walking's effects on cognitive decline, mood, cardiovascular function, and other secondary outcomes are pending. The trial retains sufficient power to address its aims despite COVID-19-related adjustments.
population_specificity: Independently living adults aged 60-90 years without cognitive impairment, recruited from retirement villages and the wider community in Australia.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a 10-week eHealth-supported motor-cognitive training program improves walking capacity in individuals with Parkinson's disease compared to a standard paper-based exercise program.
results_summary: The study protocol outlines a comparison between motor-cognitive eHealth training and paper-based exercises, with walking capacity (assessed via the six-minute walk test) as the primary outcome. Secondary outcomes include gait performance, balance, and physical activity behavior, but results are not yet reported as the study is ongoing.
population_specificity: Individuals with mild to moderate Parkinson's disease (n=120).
effective_dosage: 10-week individualized motor-cognitive eHealth training (intervention group) or paper-based home exercise program (control group).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the strength and quality of existing evidence regarding the efficacy of VR training in improving motor performance, ADL, and QoL outcomes in patients with Parkinson's disease.
results_summary: VR training showed large improvements in basic balance ability, moderate improvements in overall balance capacity, stride length, ADL, and QoL, but no clear evidence of benefit for walking speed, motor function, or gait function. The evidence quality ranged from moderate to very low.
population_specificity: Patients with Parkinson's disease

study_goal: The researchers aimed to analyze the uptake rate of the Parkinson's Disease core outcome set (COS) in clinical trials, particularly focusing on outcomes like 'Walking and Balance.'
results_summary: The study found that 'Walking and Balance' had the highest COS uptake rate among the outcomes analyzed, but overall, there was no significant increase in COS uptake post-publication. Heterogeneity in measurement instruments and unmeasured outcomes were noted.
population_specificity: Adults with Parkinson's Disease participating in phase III/IV clinical trials.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to summarize recent findings on treatment targets for peripheral artery disease (PAD)-related limb ischemia, including the role of walking and exercise therapy.
results_summary: The study found that most people with PAD require treatment to improve walking and function, but current options like exercise therapy have limitations such as poor uptake and limited efficacy. New therapies, including improved exercise programs, are under development.
population_specificity: Individuals with peripheral artery disease (PAD).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of supervised group-based walking and non-supervised individual-based walking interventions on frailty, cognitive function, and quality of life among inactive older adults in Saudi Arabia.
results_summary: The study did not report specific results in the abstract but aimed to examine the effects of different walking interventions on frailty, cognitive function, and quality of life immediately after a 16-week intervention and 12 weeks post-intervention.
population_specificity: Inactive older adults (ages 55-64) in Saudi Arabia.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether weight support feedback walker (WSFW) gait training could reduce walker dependence, improve lower limb muscle activation, and enhance gait ability in patients with incomplete spinal cord injury (ISCI).
results_summary: The WSFW group showed a significant decrease in walker dependence compared to the conventional walker (CW) group, suggesting WSFW training may help patients transfer body weight to the paralyzed lower extremity. However, the study concluded that further randomized controlled trials with larger samples are needed to verify these effects.
population_specificity: Eleven subjects with incomplete spinal cord injury (ISCI) capable of walking >20 meters with and without a walker.
effective_dosage: 30 minutes per day, three times per week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the impact of a multicomponent exercise program, including walking, on inspiratory muscle strength in oldest-old hospitalized patients with acute illness.
results_summary: The intervention group showed improved maximal inspiratory pressure (MIP) at discharge, particularly in women, reaching expected reference levels. Patients with inspiratory muscle weakness at admission demonstrated significant improvement after the intervention.
population_specificity: Oldest-old hospitalized patients (mean age 87) with acute illness.
effective_dosage: Two daily sessions of supervised walking, squats, balance exercises, and inspiratory muscle training.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine bidirectional relationships between momentary fatigue and physical activity (including walking) in people with subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH) suffering from chronic fatigue.
results_summary: The study found that higher physical activity (including walking) was associated with increased subsequent fatigue, and higher fatigue was associated with reduced subsequent physical activity. These bidirectional associations varied significantly among participants.
population_specificity: 38 people with SAH (mean age 53.2 years, 58% female) suffering from chronic fatigue, mean time post-SAH onset was 9.5 months.
effective_dosage: Not specified (PA was measured continuously via accelerometer).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of progressive vs. constant intensity resistance training and low-intensity walking on fibromyalgia symptoms, including walking ability.
results_summary: The abstract describes the study protocol but does not report results, as it is a planned randomized controlled trial.
population_specificity: Individuals with fibromyalgia.
effective_dosage: 40-minute treadmill walk at low intensity (60-70% of maximum heart rate).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether manual wheelchair (MWC) skills training improves MWC skills capacity in children and adolescents compared to usual care, and to explore its influence on self-efficacy, participation satisfaction, and parent-perceived skills.
results_summary: The study protocol outlines a randomized controlled trial to evaluate the effectiveness of MWC skills training, but results are not yet available as it describes the planned methodology and objectives.
population_specificity: Children and adolescents who use manual wheelchairs, recruited from rehabilitation centers, specialized schools, and communities in three Canadian cities.
effective_dosage: 12 sessions, 45-60 minutes each, delivered 1-2 times per week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare post-operative recovery, specifically the ability to mobilize safely within 6 hours of surgery, between spinal anaesthesia and general anaesthesia in fast-track hip and knee arthroplasty patients.
results_summary: The study focuses on the primary outcome of safe mobilization (5-m walking test within 6 hours post-surgery) and secondary outcomes like discharge criteria, pain, dizziness, nausea, and patient-reported recovery. Results are pending as the abstract describes the study design rather than findings.
population_specificity: Patients undergoing total hip (THA), total knee (TKA), or unicompartmental knee arthroplasty (UKA) in a fast-track setup.
effective_dosage: Not applicable (study compares anaesthetic methods, not walking dosage).
study_duration: Data collected from surgery until discharge, with 30-day follow-up for hospital contacts.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of a non-supervised mHealth intervention promoting walking and osteogenic physical activity on bone mineral density (BMD) in premenopausal women.
results_summary: The intervention group showed significant improvements in femoral neck BMD and physical fitness compared to the control group, suggesting the mHealth-guided walking program effectively enhanced bone health.
population_specificity: 60 premenopausal women aged 35-50 years (46 completed the study).
effective_dosage: At least 10,000 steps daily and 60 impacts over 4 g of acceleration.

study_goal: To investigate the effects of cycling on walking outcomes in adults with stroke.
results_summary: Cycling interventions improved walking capacity (6.1 to 63.0 m in the six-minute walk test) and gait velocity (0.01 to 0.21 m/sec). Moderate- to high-intensity aerobic training with 24+ sessions yielded the greatest improvements.
population_specificity: Adults with stroke
effective_dosage: Moderate- to high-intensity aerobic training, 24+ sessions

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the efficacy of transitional care, including its effects on walking speed, for patients with stroke after hospital discharge.
results_summary: Transitional care improved post-stroke motor performance, walking speed, and activities of daily living (ADLs), while also reducing caregiver burden. The meta-analysis of 23 studies involving 2966 patients supported these findings.
population_specificity: Patients with stroke transitioning from hospital to home.
